title: Caster Semenya given London 2012 gold medal after rival is stripped of title
text:
Caster Semenya given London 2012 gold medal after rival is stripped of title • Mariya Savinova-Farnosova handed four-year doping ban by Cas • Semenya takes Russian’s 800m Olympic and 2011 world titles as result Mariya Savinova-Farnosova reacts after winning the 800m final at London 2012, with Caster Semenya coming in as runner-up. Photograph: Anja Niedringhaus/AP Caster Semenya given London 2012 gold medal after rival is stripped of title • Mariya Savinova-Farnosova handed four-year doping ban by Cas • Semenya takes Russian’s 800m Olympic and 2011 world titles as result View more sharing options Friday 10 February 2017 12.58 GMT Last modified on Friday 10 February 2017 13.36 GMT 
Mariya Savinova-Farnosova has been given a four-year doping ban by the court of arbitration for sport and been stripped of her London 2012 800m gold. 
The 31-year-old, better known by her maiden name of Savinova, also loses her 2011 world outdoor title, 2013 world silver medal and 2010 European gold. 
Savinova’s Olympic gold and 2011 world title now go to South Africa’s Caster Semenya , making her a double Olympic champion, while Britain’s Jenny Meadows’ European bronze is upgraded to silver. 
Cas ruled that Savinova was “found to have been engaged in using doping” from July 2010 until August 2013. 
In 2014, Savinova was caught in undercover footage filmed by the Russian doping whistleblower Yulia Stepanova appearing to admit to injecting testosterone and taking the banned steroid oxandrolone. The footage helped to spark a World Anti-Doping Agency investigation into Russia.
